description: {"blocks":[{"key":"4teuj","text":"Abstract","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f7cc5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4vqhb","text":"This protocol was developed by Uppsala Svampklubb (fungal society), in cooperation with Evolutionary Biology Centre (EBC) at Uppsala University, as a cost efficient method to help amateurs with fungal species identification using DNA sequences. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3hn1s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ftvbq","text":"The advantage of Nanopore technology is that over 2000 samples can be sequenced at the same time, thereby significantly lowering the cost per sample. The more that is sequenced at the same time, the cheaper it becomes per sample. The main challenge is to balance a high enough success rate with a low cost per sample, which is fairly optimized in this protocol, especially for agarics.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7fmko","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6apjb","text":"The protocol follows the process all the way from collecting fungi in the field to having a library of DNA ready for sequencing. It yields an 85% success rate for mushrooms and toadstools (fairly easy to sequence). Hydnoids, polypores and corticioids usually also works well. Ascomycetes are usually more difficult but works with some tweaking of the protocol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"52m22","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f7rf6","text":"Time required:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cslpg","text":"Time consumption is shown on a note in the fist step of each section. steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"shvu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9kl75","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"53v4i","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4c00m","text":"Before starting:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ck04s","text":"In order to maximize the chances that your barcoding is successful there are several things to consider when collecting, storing and documenting your fungal specimens. Collections coupled with a DNA sequence are also more valuable when donated to a herbarium (a voucher), in which case it is important to properly conserve them so that they meet the standards of the herbarium. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cobg3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dm35d","text":"Some things to consider:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eane1","text":"When possible collect many fruit bodies in the field. Larger collections are better than small ones since material is constantly being used for research. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dktdi","text":"Document the finding. Minimum parameters for herbarium donations are: date, region, locality and coordinates. The locality should be described as detailed as possible in case the coordinates are wrong. Specimens should preferably be determined to at least genus level.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d21eb","text":"Specimens should be dried in 30-35 °C until they are completely dry. The optimal temperature depends on the type of fungus and other factors. DNA might be damaged if the temperature is too high, or the specimen is dried too quickly, or too slowly. If specimens are dried too slowly they also often get eaten by worms and insects. Room temperature is often sufficient for fungi with lower water content, e.g. many hard wood living fungi such as polypores and corticioids. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3pe63","text":"Very large specimens should be sliced into several thinner pieces before drying in order to fit in herbarium sheets.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"62srf","text":"If the fungus is an epifyte on a fragile plant it is good to use a plant press or similar.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"32lh3","text":"Store the specimens as dark as possible as light exposure destroys DNA over time. Properly dried and stored collections lasts at least a few years before DNA deteriorates to a level that makes sequencing harder.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8d60m","text":"Keep a database, e.g. an excel sheet, with all your data on the collected specimens. It is practical to assign personal collection numbers to your specimens which can be used to keep track of them when they enter the barcoding stage or are deposited to a herbarium.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3l1is","text":"Report the finding to an observation database such as iNaturalist or Artportalen (in Sweden).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"38jc4","text":"Time consumption: Field work and collection handling takes around 25-30 hours / 96 samples (1 PCR plate).","type":"unstyled"}],"collapsed":true,"entityMap":{},"guid":"9F2B0DA2FED844EAB27CCE50147913D0"}}}}

The volume you transfer depend on how much DNA there was in your PCR plate. A PCR plate with a low success rate (fewer cells with successful amplification = less total DNA) of around 30% may require 300 µL, while a high success rate may require 100 µL. If you performed gel electrophoresis on the plate you will know the success rate. Otherwise it can often be estimated by the proportions of easy vs. difficult fungi in the plate. Mushrooms, toadstools etc are relatively easy while wood-living fungi, hydnoids and many ascomycetes are examples of more difficult groups, often with lower success rates in this protocol. Estimating which species are easy vs. difficult requires some experience. {"blocks":[{"key":"e7lmg","text":"Add   of the mastermix you prepared in step   to each cell on the plate using a dispenser pipette. Be careful when using the dispenser pipette! {"blocks":[{"key":"mu71","text":"Add   of nuclease-free water to the strips in order to dilute the samples. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":4,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7f1l6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"81ng6","text":"-\u003e The 1:50 dilution have proven to be sufficient for most mushrooms and toadstools. However, different genera often require different dilutions depending on the amount of DNA and PCR inhibitors present in the material. Strongly pigmented fungi often require a higher dilution. What method works the best for certain fungal groups is highly experience based. In some cases even a 1:1000 dilution may work better. In this step we have diluted the sample to 1:20. Later, in the PCR protocol, we also reduced the initial template volume from 1.4 to 0.5 in order to achieve a ~1:50 dilution. If you think that a higher dilution (\u003e1:60) is necessary, you will need to use an extra set of tubes and pipette tips in this step (dilute further in new tubes). {"blocks":[{"key":"9o3e7","text":"Pipette   of Mason \u0026 Botella (2020) extraction buffer (20 mM Tris (pH 8), 25 mM NaCl, 2.5 mM EDTA, 0.05% (wt/vol) SDS, and 2% (wt/vol) PVP-40) in each tube with tissue using a dispensing pipette or multipipette. This step can be done in the lab both before and after placing the tissue in the tubes. We recommend that it is done beforehand since the tissue is easier to stick in the tubes when there is liquid inside. Static electricity can otherwise make it difficult to handle small pieces of tissue in plastic {"blocks":[{"key":"ap884","text":"Consider performing step   before this step.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":25,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7aku2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"29gvk","text":"Put a very small piece of tissue in each tube. Usually   or 1-2 mm2 is well enough for this manual and one can often use even smaller amounts. The amount of tissue can be changed for different species if needed but keep in mind that one may also need to change the amount of buffer when doing so in order to maintain optimal dilution. If you are new to this protocol it is a good idea to calibrate your weight/mass perception of different fungal species beforehand using a high resolution lab scale. Later, when doing this at home, you will then be better at estimating amounts. It is often preferable to choose tissue from the fertile part of the fungus, i.e. the hymenium containing spores.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":66,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":55,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ap7hm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c9rf3","text":"Dried tissue can be broken off from the fungus using e.g. a scalpel or tweezers and a white paper. Choose a piece that is close to the desired size and put it in the tube. Toothpicks are very useful for putting small pieces of tissue into the tubes. Between specimens, wipe the scalpel or tweezer with paper. If you want to be extra careful, dip it in ethanol before wiping. {"blocks":[{"key":"diu18","text":"Put the specimens in numerical order on your work bench with regards to the pairing of your personal collection numbers with the row-column (number-letter) combination on the 96 tubes. The collection assigned to tube 1A should be placed first in order etc. for efficient DNA extraction. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2j7dl","text":"Assign your fungal specimens to a row and column number in your excel data sheet.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aj2a8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dmlb0","text":"It is very important that you keep track of which collection belongs which tube. Without this information you will later have no way of knowing which DNA sequence belong to which collection.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"av0qg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"459nd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"32ilj","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"amfsl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bl9a2","text":"Start with laying out (96) 0.2 mL-tubes (12X 8-strips) with individual caps on a 96-well PCR plate rack. Label the tubes with their row and column number in the plate, i.e. a combination of columns 1-12 and row A-H (1A-12H). Also label each 8-strip with the pIate number. It is convenient to use two plate racks, one as your current workspace and one with your completed strips. {"blocks":[{"key":"526b9","text":"Save point: The tubes with diluted DNA will be used in the following section (PCR protocol) and can be stored in the fridge overnight. For long term storage both the tubes with tissue and dilution can be stored in the freezer without degrading the DNA. The DNA will only degrade after repeated freezing and thawing which should not be a problem here. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2chfn","text":"Save point: The primer plate should be stored in the freezer. The PCR plate can after amplification be stored in the fridge for short term storage (a few days) and in the freezer for long term storage. IMPORTANT: The PCR plate can not be stored before amplification as the primers will malfunction.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cb65u","text":"Save point: Tubes with cleaned amplicons can be stored in the fridge until the start of the next section.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6e7dj","text":"Save point: Store the pool tubes in the fridge until you have successfully completed the protocol. If something goes wrong during the rest of the protocol, the pool tubes are your lifeline and you can start over from this point. When the protocol is completed, they can be stored in the freezer.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7v6tj","text":"Save point: End-prepped DNA can be stored in the fridge until the start of the next section.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fitj1","text":"Save point: If the protocol is too long to be completed in one go, the barcoded sample can be stored at   overnight.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":104,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"EFCCDFF6C6A311EE8E1D0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"4","unit":10}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2et3o","text":"Save point: The prepared library is used for loading on the the flowcell of the nanopore device. Store the library at   for short term or repeated use. For long term (more than 3 months) or single use store the library at   in LowBind tubes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":118,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":222,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"1F6E2C9AC6A411EE8E1D0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"4","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"1F6E2D24C6A411EE8E1D0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"-80","unit":10}}}}
